plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub known for its large, showy flowers that appear in late winter through early spring. Camellias are prized in gardens for their glossy leaves and long-lasting blooms during cold months.
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide, native to East Asia (Japan, China, Korea)
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica was named after the Jesuit botanist Georg Kamel and was one of the first Asian plants introduced to Europe in the 18th century.

plants.name: Erica carnea
plants.description: A low-growing evergreen shrub that blooms in late winter to early spring, often when snow still covers the ground. Known for small bell-shaped flowers that brighten winter gardens.
plants.location: Central and Southern Europe, in mountainous and heathland areas
plants.funFact: Winter Heath is one of the few plants that can flower under snow, providing vital nectar for bees early in the year.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: A hardy evergreen shrub that can bloom in mild winter climates. In subtropical to tropical regions, it may flower nearly year-round, including January.
plants.bloomingSeason: May to October, but often year-round in frost-free areas
plants.location: Mediterranean Basin, parts of California, Australia, and India
plants.funFact: Despite its beauty, all parts of the oleander plant are toxic if ingested, containing cardiac glycosides.

plants.name: Banksia integrifolia
plants.description: A native Australian tree that flowers in various seasons depending on climate, including summer and winter months. Its cylindrical flower spikes attract nectar-feeding birds and mammals.
plants.bloomingSeason: Year-round, with peaks in summer and winter
plants.funFact: Banksias are named after Sir Joseph Banks, botanist on Captain Cookâ€™s first voyage to Australia.
